Question Text: Which of the following are examples of control plane operations? Select all that apply.
Choices:
a. Rate-limiting traffic so that the overall sending rate does not exceed a certain throughput.
b. Determining that a user's MAC address is authentic before allowing it to send traffic on the network.
c. Load balancing traffic across two output ports based on the hash of each packet's source IP address.
d. Determining the forwarding path that satisfies an access control policy.
e. Computing a shortest path routing tree.
LLM Explanation: Control plane operations involve making decisions about how data traffic should be handled, rather than the actual forwarding of packets. Determining the forwarding path that satisfies an access control policy (d) and computing a shortest path routing tree (e) are control plane functions as they decide how packets should be routed without actually moving the packets. The other options involve data plane operations - rate limiting (a), MAC authentication (b), and load balancing (c) all manipulate or filter the data packets themselves.
URLs: ['Software Defined Networks: A Comprehensive Approach, Second Edition by Paul Goransson, Chuck Black', 'https://www.sdxcentral.com/networking/sdn/definitions/inside-sdn-architecture/', 'https://www.networkcomputing.com/networking/understanding-sdn-control-plane']

Question Text: What could be the operational steps behind the AT&T's IRSCP (a commercial version of the Routing Control Platform) for detecting malicious traffic? Select all that apply.
Choices:
a. The controller sees all traffic passing through the network, detects an attack, and installs a null route to drop traffic at the entry point where the attack traffic is originating.
b. The end host changes its IP address so that it is no longer the target of the attack traffic.
c. A measurement system detects an attack, identifies the entry point of the attack, and instructs a controller to re-route traffic through a deep-packet inspection device.
d. A measurement system detects an attack, identifies the entry point of the attack, and instructs a controller to install a null route to drop traffic at the entry point where attack traffic is originating.
e. A victim end host sends an alert to an on-path firewall about the source and nature of an attack, at which point the firewall installs a null route to drop the traffic at the entry point where the attack is originating.
LLM Explanation: The correct steps for AT&T's IRSCP in detecting and mitigating malicious traffic are: c) A measurement system detects an attack, identifies the entry point, and instructs the controller to re-route the traffic through a deep-packet inspection device for further analysis.d) A measurement system detects an attack, identifies the entry point, and instructs the controller to install a null route to drop the malicious traffic at the entry point.The controller itself does not see all the traffic to detect attacks (a). Changing the end host IP (b) or the end host alerting an on-path firewall (e) are not part of the IRSCP operational steps.

Question Text: What are some example network management applications that become easier with control and data plane separation? Select all that apply.
Choices:
a. Improved interdomain routing security.
b. Customer-controlled egress selection.
c. Improved logging capabilities.
d. Planned maintenance of an edge router.
e. Forecasting of network capacity.
LLM Explanation: With the separation of control and data planes in SDN, certain network management tasks become easier. Customer-controlled egress selection (b) is simplified because the control plane has a global network view and can intelligently select egress points based on customer preferences. Planned maintenance of an edge router (d) is also easier because traffic can be rerouted by the control plane to avoid the router being serviced, minimizing disruption. While SDN may provide some security and logging benefits, interdomain routing security (a) and logging capabilities (c) are not the key advantages of control/data plane separation. Forecasting network capacity (e) is also not directly simplified by this separation.
URLs: ['Software Defined Networks: A Comprehensive Approach by Paul Goransson and Chuck Black, Chapter 4: SDN Architecture and Protocols', 'https://www.networkworld.com/article/3209131/what-sdn-is-and-where-its-going.html']

Question Text: What are some of the motivations for using Layer-2 forwarding in a data center? Select all that apply.
Choices:
a. Ability to use existing routing protocols to establish paths between hosts.
b. Easier configuration/administration, since there is no need to number hosts or configure subnets.
c. Better security properties.
d. Better scaling properties.
e. Better load balancing properties.
LLM Explanation: The main motivations for using Layer-2 forwarding in a data center are:b) Easier configuration and administration, since there is no need to assign IP addresses to hosts or configure IP subnets. This simplifies network management.  d) Better scaling properties compared to Layer-3 routing. Layer-2 forwarding allows the use of flat addressing, which can scale to very large numbers of hosts without exhausting IP address space or requiring complex subnetting.While existing routing protocols can still be used at the edge (a), they are not needed for host-to-host forwarding within the Layer-2 fabric. Security (c) and load balancing (e) are not inherently better with Layer-2 compared to Layer-3 approaches.

Question Text: How does the separation of the control and data plane make networking in data centers easier?
Choices:
a. Virtual machines can be migrated within the network without renumbering entire portions of the network or re-assigning network services to different IP addresses.
b. The control plane allows traffic to be forwarded using Layer 2 addresses, thus allowing automatic load balance across the topology.
c. The separation allows fewer switches to be used in the data center topology, thus lowering costs.
d. All routes can be controlled and monitored from a central point of control.
e. A network controller can permit the renumbering of end hosts to have topology-dependent Layer 2 MAC addresses.
LLM Explanation: The separation of control and data planes in software defined networking allows for easier management of data center networks. With a centralized control plane, virtual machines can be migrated within the network without the need to renumber IP addresses or reassign network services (a). Additionally, having a central point of control allows for easier monitoring and management of all routes in the network (d). The other options are incorrect - SDN does not inherently use Layer 2 forwarding (b), reduce the number of switches needed (c), or require topology-dependent MAC addresses (e).
URLs: ['Software Defined Networks: A Comprehensive Approach by Paul Goransson and Chuck Black', 'Software-Defined Networking (SDN) Definition - https://www.opennetworking.org/sdn-definition/']

Question Text: What are some examples of problems that can arise from consistency problems in the control plane, where a network has multiple controller replicas?
Choices:
a. A flood of traffic at the controller.
b. Inability to respond to link failures.
c. Incorrect security policies.
d. Incorrect operation when one controller fails.
e. Forwarding loops.
LLM Explanation: Consistency problems between multiple controller replicas in the control plane of a software-defined network can lead to several issues:b. Inability to respond to link failures - If controllers have inconsistent network state, they may not properly detect and react to link failures.  c. Incorrect security policies - Inconsistent controller state can result in security policies being applied incorrectly or not at all across the network.d. Incorrect operation when one controller fails - If a controller fails, inconsistencies with remaining controllers can cause the network to operate incorrectly.e. Forwarding loops - Inconsistent flow rules programmed by out-of-sync controllers can create forwarding loops in the data plane.While a flood of controller traffic (a) is a potential issue in SDN, it's not a direct result of control plane inconsistencies.
URLs: ["https://ieeexplore.ieee.org/document/7524435 - 'Consistency Issues in Software-Defined Networks' discusses various problems arising from control plane inconsistencies.", "https://dl.acm.org/doi/10.1145/2620728.2620752 - 'Consistency in Software Defined Networks' covers consistency issues and their network impacts."]

Question Text: What are some approaches to coping with inconsistency across controller replicas? Select all that apply.
Choices:
a. Running a consistency protocol across controller replicas.
b. Keeping a "hot spare" replica that has a complete view of the network state.
c. Only keeping a subset of the network state in memory at any time.
d. Using different controllers for independent parts of the network.
e. Having multiple controllers install forwarding table entries on the same router and resolving the conflict on the router itself.
LLM Explanation: Two approaches to coping with inconsistency across controller replicas are:a) Running a consistency protocol across the replicas to ensure they maintain the same network state. This allows the replicas to synchronize their views.  d) Using different controllers for independent parts of the network. By partitioning the network, each controller only needs to maintain consistency for its assigned portion, reducing overall complexity.The other options are not ideal:b) Keeping a hot spare does not address inconsistency between active replicas. c) Only keeping a subset of state can lead to an incomplete view for any given replica.e) Having controllers compete to install entries on the same router creates additional consistency issues on the data plane itself.
URLs: ['Software Defined Networks: A Comprehensive Approach by Paul Goransson and Chuck Black, Chapter 6 - Controller Platforms', 'https://www.opennetworking.org/wp-content/uploads/2013/02/Principles_and_Practices_for_Securing_Software-Defined_Networks_applied_to_OFv1.3.4_V1.0.pdf']

Question Text: What are some approaches to coping with scalability challenges associated with control and data plane separation? Select all that apply.
Choices:
a. Caching forwarding decisions in the data plane to reduce traffic at the controller.
b. Only performing control-plane operations for a limited set of network operations.
c. Eliminating redundant data structures.
d. Sending all traffic through the controller to minimize forwarding decisions that the routers and switches must make.
e. Running multiple controllers, and having each controller only manage a part of the network.
LLM Explanation: There are a few key approaches to handling scalability challenges with the separation of control and data planes in SDN:a) Caching forwarding decisions in the data plane reduces the need for switches to query the controller for every packet, lowering controller load.  c) Eliminating redundant data structures helps optimize the use of limited memory and processing resources.e) Distributing the control plane across multiple controllers, each managing a portion of the network, allows the control plane to scale.b) Limiting control-plane operations would reduce flexibility and programmability, counter to SDN principles.d) Sending all traffic through the controller would overload it, creating a bottleneck rather than improving scalability.
URLs: ['Kreutz, D., Ramos, F., Verissimo, P., Rothenberg, C. E., Azodolmolky, S., & Uhlig, S. (2015). Software-defined networking: A comprehensive survey. Proceedings of the IEEE, 103(1), 14-76.', 'Yeganeh, S. H., Tootoonchian, A., & Ganjali, Y. (2013, August). On scalability of software-defined networking. IEEE Communications Magazine, 51(2), 136-141.', 'Karakus, M., & Durresi, A. (2017). A survey: Control plane scalability issues and approaches in software-defined networking (SDN). Computer Networks, 112, 279-293.']

Question Text: Which property guarantees that each RCP replica continues to install correct forwarding state in the network data plane, even in the case of a partition in the data plane?
Choices:
a. Each controller has a complete view of the portion of the network that it is controlling, and therefore can guarantee consistent routing within that partition.
b. The controller cannot see many of the routers in the network anyway, so there is no way for it to install incorrect routing state in the routers that it is not connected to.
c. The controllers are partitioned from the network routers, and the routers will fall back to running a distributed routing protocol.
d. Running the network from a single high-level control plane guarantees that network partitions and loops never occur in the first place.
LLM Explanation: Each controller has a complete view of the portion of the network it is controlling. This allows the controller to guarantee consistent routing within its partition, even if the data plane becomes partitioned. The controller can still install correct forwarding state in the routers it has visibility of and control over.
